An interesting op-ed recently published in the Denver Post written by David Harsanyi.
 
 
Harsanyi: Abortion debate changing
 As an atheist and a secular kinda guy, I practice moral relativism regularly. Still, I've always struggled mightily with the ethics and politics of abortion. Apparently, I'm not alone.
 
 A new Gallup poll claims that for the first time since 1995, when the question was first asked by the organization, most Americans consider themselves to be "pro-life" rather than "pro-choice."
 
 The straightforward question asked of participants was this: "With respect to the abortion issue, would you consider yourself to be pro-choice or pro-life?" Fifty-one percent responded that they were pro-life and 42 percent said they were pro-choice. These percentages are the reverse found in the same poll in 2006.
 
 What happened? Is it possible that the nation has undergone a gigantic attitudinal shift on the fundamental issue of abortion in only three years' time? Logically, it seems that the entire framing of the debate has become antiquated and far too simplistic for the questions we face. Anecdotally, I would say it's possible.
 
 I know I've changed my views.
 
 After a life of being pro-choice, I began to seriously ponder the question. I oppose the death penalty because there is a slim chance that an innocent person might be executed and I don't believe the state should have the authority to take a citizen's life. So don't I owe an nascent human life at least the same deference? Just in case?
 
 You may not consider a fetus a "human life" in early pregnancy, though it has its own DNA and medical science continues to find ways to keep the fetus viable outside the womb earlier and earlier.
 
 But it's difficult to understand how those who harp about the importance of "science" in public policy can draw an arbitrary timeline in the pregnancy, defining when human life is worth saving and when it can be terminated.
 
 The more I thought about it, the creepier the issue got.
 
 Newsweek, for instance, recently reported that 90 percent of women whose fetuses test positive for Down syndrome choose an abortion. Another survey showed only a small percentage of mothers even used the test. So what happens when 90 percent of parents test their fetuses? Does it mean the end of the disease or are we stepping perilously close to eugenics?
 
 What about future DNA tests that can detect any "defects" in a fetus? What happens when we can use abortion to weed out the blind, mentally ill, the ugly, or any other any "undesirable" human being?
 
 Recently, Sweden's National Board of Health and Welfare ruled that women are permitted to abort their children based on the sex of the fetus. In the United States, a woman can have an abortion for nearly any reason she chooses. In fact, a health exemption for the mother allows abortions to be performed virtually on demand.
 
 If you oppose selective abortions, but not abortion overall, I wonder why? How is terminating the fetus because it's the wrong sex any worse than terminating the fetus for convenience's sake? The fate of the fetus does not change, only the reasoning for its extinction does.
 
 Now, I happen to believe (as the civil libertarian and pro-life activist Nat Hentoff once noted) that the right to life and liberty is the foundation of a moral society. Then again, I also believe a government ban on abortion would only criminalize the procedure and do little to mitigate the amount of abortions.
 
 Obviously, these are a few of the complex and uncomfortable issues to ponder. So maybe this poll tells us that the dynamics of the abortion debate are about to change, that Americans are getting past the politics and into the morality of the issue.
 
 Then again, it's entirely possible that I'm just projecting.

 This is a fair point that has been brought up in past threads that I am willing to take on since, unlike many on both sides, I will not run away from opposition's points that do not have pre-set comfortable answers.
 
 Yes, animals also can have minds - can feel suffering, fear and apprehension. Because of this, I am a strong believer in animal rights and have given money to organizations that champion it. Mainly, I think that there should be prosecutions against un-necessary cruelty against animals and against very negligent care that leads to suffering of animals that people have taken a responsibility for. 
 
 So, I do believe that animals deserve rights - particularly those that are of higher order that can actually be considered sentient. However, I do not believe that animals should have the same rights as humans. Part of this comes down to the idea that humans can form communities with fixed rules where there is a balance of rights and responsibilities that are aknowledged. Animals, though they can form social groups with some level of trends in social behavior, and even show empathy on occasion, do not have a concept of rules or responsibilities or any understanding of a concept of rights. They are incapable of even grasping the idea of rights or rules. Any rules that domesticated animals follow are simply based on learning that certain behaviors are automatically connected to punishments. Given the danger that animals can pose if left unrestrained, they simply cannot have the same rights as people.
 
 One can claim that there are people of mental disability that might have the same limitations in mental abilities as animals so why should animals have different rights than those people? That is where the second, not as morally comfortable point, comes in. Namely, if we were to give animals the same rights as even our mentally disabled people have, then we would not long survive as a species. We need to be able to control our food supplies - which often involves killing infestations of pests. We need to defend ourselves against infestations of rats and insects that can carry diseases. There are many situations where treating animals as we treat ourselves would lead to the demise of the human race. I personally don't have many moral qualms in giving preferential treatment to those of my own species to ensure its survival - as long as there are restraints on how humans treat animals that limit negative treatment to that which is necessary. 
 
 On a last note on this point, a core part of my moral stance is to treat others as I would expect to be treated. This is part of a moral "deal" in which I treat others as I would expect to be treated but, in return, expect to also be treated fairly. I believe that most people approach morality from a similar point of view - one which has been described both in religious texts and in philosophical ones. However, there are situations in human experience where such moral consensus completely breaks down - as in the worst phases of war. In that case, far too many people break that moral consensus for one to have any trust in its continued existence. So, people who still have a conscience often default back to protecting their own, while limiting any negative behavior against others to that which is necessary. I would say that that situation has similarities to how one treats animals. With animals, there can be no moral consensus since they are incapable of making such a consensus. So, one defaults back to protecting ones own (the human species) while limiting negative behavior toward others (non-humans).
 
 -----
 
 As for the more general concept of what defines a person, this is clearly a philosophical question that is being debated. Some try to argue purely from semantics but I have always found that to be an arguement that leads nowhere since semantics only work if there is agreement on terms - which there isn't in the case of the concept of people and rights. So, mainly unsuccessfully, we here try to convince each other of our ideas of these concepts. The reality is that, so far, despite the ideas of various layment, there seems to be legal consensus that Constitutional rights begin at birth. Of course, the pro-life side is trying to push that earlier, which it has every right to try to do since, after all, we are a Democracy. However, there have been far more failures in this than successes (as demonstrated, even recently, by that failures in Colorado and South Dakota in trying to formally have embryos/fetuses be called people with rights). So, your arguments do not seem to be working in convincing most people of your view. However, I believe that you would be far more successful if you at least approached it piecemeal by arguing first for the rights of late term fetuses (where there is far more consensus on their rights) than by arguing for the rights of all pre-born (embryos and zygotes included) since there is much less consensus on early-term rights than on late-term rights. You would even find many on the pro-choice side, myself included, arguing with you for late term fetal rights.

Congressman Dave Obey on George W. Bush and unemployment:
 
With President Bush pushing forward with his economic policy that has helped create a massive unemployment crisis, a closer analysis of the employment data shows that this crisis has now spread to almost every corner of the nation.  TWENTY-FOUR CITIES LOST OVER 4% OF THEIR WORKFORCE SINCE BUSH TOOK OFFICE: According to BLS data, more than 24 major cities in America have lost more than 4% of their entire workforce since Bush took office. Among the worst hit are Boulder, CO which has lost 16.7% of its workforce; San Jose, CA which has lost 15.9% of its workforce; San Francisco, CA which has lost 10.2% of its workforce; Flint, MI which has lost 7.7% of its workforce; and Greenville, SC which has lost 6.8% of its workforce.
 
 37 STATES AND 173 CITIES HAVE LOST JOBS SINCE BUSH TOOK OFFICE: Out of 300 city/metropolitan areas and 50 states surveyed, 173 cities and 37 states have seen their workforces reduced since Bush took office.
 
 MORE THAN 2 MILLION JOBS LOST SINCE BUSH TOOK OFFICE: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), total non-farm employment in January 2001 was 132,413,900. The latest data from January 2003 shows that total non-farm employment is now 130,089,400 - a loss of more than 2.3 million jobs in just two years.
 
 EMPLOYMENT WAS STILL RISING WHEN BUSH TOOK OFFICE: During the months of Oct, Nov, Dec of 2000, the three months prior to the Bush inauguration, nearly 300,000 jobs were added to the economy.
